section.title: An ED Caught in the Middle CASE STUDY #5
section.content: An ED Caught in the Middle CASE STUDY #5 Advanced EMTALA Training

section.related-content: An adult male presented to the hospital Emergency Department. He passed out after drinking alcohol. The patient had a previous history of a heart attack and cardiac stent placement. He was on Plavix (a blood clot inhibitor).
Upon arrival to the Emergency Department, the patient’s systolic blood pressure was in the 70s.
A chest x-ray and abdominal CT were done. They revealed bleeding in the abdomen.
The patient was treated with intravenous fluids, blood products, and a Dopamine infusion.
The ED physician made several attempts to contact the on-call surgeon.
After the fourth call, the surgeon responded to the page. He came in to the ED about forty five minutes later. By now, two hours had elapsed from the time the patient initially presented to the ED.

The on-call surgeon reviewed the medical record prior to assessing the patient. During this time, the patient’s wife came out to the nurse’s station and asked the surgeon why he was so late. The surgeon became upset and made a derogatory comment.

The wife said she’d take her husband to another hospital; and the surgeon said OK. The wife apologized and asked the surgeon to please take care of her husband. The surgeon refused to take the patient to the operating room.

The ED physicians also insisted that he operate on the patient. When the surgeon continued to refuse, the ED physicians continued to support the patient’s blood pressure with IV fluids and medication.
The patient was eventually transferred to another hospital. He had surgery shortly after admission.
An EMTALA complaint was filed by the recipient hospital alleging ‘patient dumping’.
